title: 108_s2242
content: The Act may be cited as the "Anticounterfeiting Act of 2004". Congress recognizes the critical role of American innovation and government protection in driving economic growth. Copyright-based industries are a significant economic asset, contributing over 5% of the GDP and employing 4.3 million people. The proliferation of criminal counterfeiting enterprises poses a threat to the growth of these industries. The American intellectual property sector invests in sophisticated authentication features to combat counterfeiting. Counterfeiters tamper with genuine authentication features to evade industry efforts. Federal law lacks adequate remedies to address tampering activities facilitating counterfeiting crimes. Congress must enact legislation to strengthen Federal enforcement against counterfeiting of copyrighted works. To combat counterfeiting of copyrighted works, Congress should pass laws prohibiting trafficking and tampering with authentication features, while also allowing affected parties to pursue civil action. PROHIBITION AGAINST TRAFFICKING IN ILLICIT AUTHENTICATION FEATURES. The amendment to Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit authentication features, or counterfeit documentation or packaging. This includes trafficking in counterfeit labels affixed to phonorecords, computer programs, motion pictures, or documentation/packaging, as well as illicit authentication features affixed to phonorecords. The amendment to Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit authentication features, or counterfeit documentation or packaging, including those affixed to phonorecords, computer programs, motion pictures, or audiovisual works. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. The term 'authentication feature' refers to physical features used by copyright owners to verify authenticity of products. 'Documentation or packaging' refers to materials accompanying products. 'Illicit authentication feature' is an unauthorized authentication feature. The term 'authentication feature' refers to physical features used by copyright owners to verify authenticity of products. It can be tampered with or altered to facilitate reproduction or distribution of copyrighted materials without authorization. This includes phonorecords, computer programs, motion pictures, and documentation or packaging. The unauthorized distribution of genuine authentication features is also prohibited. Subsection (c) addresses the handling of illicit authentication features. Subsection (c) addresses counterfeit labels or illicit authentication features affixed to copyrighted materials like sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, and documentation or packaging. The section addresses counterfeit labels or illicit authentication features on copyrighted materials, allowing for civil remedies for copyright owners affected by violations. The court has the discretion to grant injunctions, order impounding of articles, and award attorney fees, costs, actual damages, and additional damages in actions brought under this section to prevent violations of copyright law. The court may award actual damages, additional profits, or statutory damages in copyright violation cases. Actual damages include the injured party's losses and any profits gained by the violator. The court calculates actual damages in copyright violation cases by multiplying the value of counterfeit items by the number of items, unless underestimating harm. The court calculates actual damages in copyright violation cases by multiplying the value of counterfeit items by the number of items, unless underestimating harm. Statutory damages can be elected instead of actual damages and profits, with a minimum sum specified for each violation. The court may impose fines ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 for violations of this section, with the possibility of tripling the damages for subsequent violations within 3 years. Civil actions must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation, and liability under other copyright sections remains unaffected. The item relating to section 2318 in the table of sections at the beginning of chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code, is amended by inserting "or illicit authentication features" after "counterfeit labels".
